LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  People’s Republic of Bangladesh

Project  The Project has four components: (i) construction of 353 kilometers (km) 
Description  of gas transmission pipelines for transporting 360 million cubic feet per 
  day (MMCFD) of natural gas to expand the gas supply network to the less 
  developed region of the country, (ii) field appraisal and survey of an area 
  of about 1,250 km2 encompassing five gas fields to delineate available 
  reserves, (iii) 200 km gas distribution network in Rajshahi area, and (iv) 
  support for building the capacity of gas sector agencies.  
   
Rationale  The relatively low utilization of natural gas in Bangladesh has constrained 
the commercial, industrial, and rural development of the country. The 
country’s  gas  infrastructure  is  in  poor  condition  due  to  a  lack  of 
commercial  orientation  and  inadequate  funding  for  maintenance  and 
expansion.  The  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy  emphasizes 
implementation of policies directed toward expanding the national gas grid 
to  cover  less  developed  regions  of  the  country,  and  to  promote 
industrialization and accelerate balanced regional development that would 
help reduce widespread poverty. In this regard, further development of the 
main  natural  energy  resource  in  Bangladesh  to  meet  the  increasing 
demand for primary commercial energy is vital. Natural gas provides 90% 
of  fuel  for  power  generation.  It  is  a  clean  source  of  energy  bringing 
significant environmental and social benefits through reduced ambient 
and indoor air pollution. 
 
Petrobangla has formulated an investment plan for oil, gas, and mineral 
resources for the period 2002–2020 that envisages investments of $3 
billion  for  the  gas  sector  including  exploration,  field  development, 
transmission, and distribution. The investment plan, which is based on a 
study financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), includes several 
projects  likely  to  be  taken  up  by  the  private  sector.  To  support  the 
investment plan, the Government developed a gas sector reform road 
map (GSRR), which will be implemented over 5 years. The GSRR covers 
(i)  institutional  and  financial  restructuring  of  gas  sector  companies  to 
ensure  long-term financial  sustainability; (ii) strengthening  public–private 
partnership in the gas sector aimed at creating an environment for private 
sector-led  growth;  (iii)  transformation  of  gas  companies  to  diversify 
ownership involving private investors; (iv) restructuring and unbundling 
gas  sector  institutions  and  enterprises;  and (v) market-oriented  energy

ii   
  pricing  reflecting  energy  parity,  eliminating  noneconomic  factors  and 
levies,  and  equating  gas  prices  from  the  state-owned  gas-producing 
companies with those from international oil companies. ADB has worked 
extensively with the Government on developing the GSRR. 
 
  ADB support is considered crucial for three main reasons: (i) to maintain 
continued policy dialogue on the development and implementation of the 
GSRR in support of the Government’s poverty reduction strategy; (ii) to 
continue dialogue on improving sector governance; and (iii) to introduce 
best practices on safeguard issues such as environment, resettlement, 
and other social matters.  
   
Impact and  The main impact of the Project is meeting gas requirements to support the 
Outcome  country’s  economic  growth.  The  primary  outcome  is  to  improve  and 
expand the natural gas infrastructure, in particular gas transmission and 
distribution network systems, by providing the most needed investment 
and field appraisal support for gas sector companies. The Project will also 
improve sector governance and ensure long-term financial viability and 
improve efficiency indicators of gas sector entities through institutional 
strengthening and implementation of the GSRR. 
 
The Project and the associated GSRR will enhance the role of the private 
sector  in  natural  gas-related  activities  including  (i)  upstream  gas 
development;  (ii)  gas  transmission  and  distribution;  and  (iii)  metering, 
audit, and operation and maintenance activities.  The private sector will 
also have an enhanced role in gas-based or related industries, power 
plants, and other manufacturing and processing activities. The Project’s 
physical  investments  are  the  most  urgent  requirements  of  the 
Government’s gas sector investment program. The Project will have the 
following components: 
 
Part A: Gas Transmission 
 
(i)  Ashuganj  west-Jamuna  Bridge  east  bank  gas  transmission 
pipeline:  construction  of  a  30-inch-diameter,  51  km  gas 
transmission pipeline from Manohardi to Dhanua and Elenga to the 
east  end  of  Jamuna  Bridge  and  installation  of  compression 
facilities at Ashuganj (west) and Elenga with a throughput of 390 
MMCFD. 
 
(ii)  Hatikumrul-Ishwardi-Bheramara  gas  transmission  pipeline: 
construction  of  a  24-inch-diameter,  87  km  gas  pipeline  from 
Hatikumrul  to  Bheramara  through  the  Sirajganj,  Natore,  Pabna 
and Kushtia districts to transmit 235 MMCFD of gas. (The pipeline 
size  may  be  increased  to  30-inch-diameter  during  the  detailed 
design stage if such change is proven prudent). 
 
(iii)  Bonpara-Rajshahi gas transmission pipeline: construction of a 12-
inch-diameter, 60 km gas pipeline from Bonpara to Rajshahi with a 
throughput of 25–30 MMCFD.

  (iv)  North–south  system  expansion:  installation  of  compressors  at

(v)  Bheramara-Khulna gas transmission pipeline: construction of a 20-

Part B: Field Appraisal  
 
Five producing gas fields will be appraised to update information on the 
estimated gas in place, and to determine the optimum location for future 
production drilling activities. The three-dimensional survey is expected to 
result  in  upgrading  proven  reserves  estimates.  No  new  exploration 
activities are involved. 
 
Part C: Rajshahi Area Gas Distribution 
 
Construction of about 320 km of 1- to 8-inch-diameter gas distribution 
network in the Rajshahi area, western Bangladesh.  
 
Part D: Capacity Building 
 
Strengthen  policy-making  capabilities  of  the  Energy  and  Mineral 
Resources Division (EMRD) of the Ministry of Power, Energy and Mineral 
Resources (MPEMR). Capacity building will include training EMRD and 
Petrobangla  and  its  companies  on  corporate  governance,  financial 
management, e-governance, and gas system management. In addition, 
this component will support the implementation of the gas sector system 
loss reduction plan.

  Poverty analysis was undertaken during project preparation. The Project’s 
poverty reduction impacts will be significant, particularly in less developed 
regions. Income levels are likely to increase due to new opportunities that 
are  expected  to  be  opened  up,  and  the  increase  in  employment 
opportunities  from  industrial  development and  other activities  related to 
  economic diversification. 
   
  The Project will create about 3,000 person-months of job opportunities for 
unskilled  labor  and  will  increase  access  to  cleaner  fuel  for  power 
generation,  transport,  and  household  use.  Air  quality  improvement  in 
urban centers and indoors will be substantial. 
 
The Project is financially sound and economically viable, with a financial 
rate of return of 12% and a minimum economic internal rate of return of 
28.1%. Sensitivity analysis indicates that the Project remains viable under 
adverse conditions.

Assumptions  commercial risks. Technical design has included adequate precautions

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh, for the Gas Transmission and Development Project. 
The project design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Natural Gas Resources 
 
2.  Natural  gas  was  discovered  in  Bangladesh  in  1955.  Opening  gas  exploration  and 
production to international oil companies (IOCs) started in the early 1990s through production 
sharing contracts (PSCs). The arrangement has contributed immensely to improved gas supply 
in recent years. Total proven and recoverable gas reserves from 22 fields (18 public sector and 
4 private sector fields) are estimated at 20.4 trillion cubic feet (TCF), of which 5.09 TCF has 
been  consumed.  Taking  discovered  and  undiscovered  reserves  together,  there  is  a  90% 
probability that Bangladesh’s gas resource will exceed 30 TCF. A recent study confirms these 
figures.1 IOC production is predicted to comprise 30–45% of supply, with the balance from state-
owned gas companies (SGC) during the next 12 years.  
 
3.  In the last decade, gas consumption in Bangladesh rose from 172.7 billion cubic feet 
(BCF) to 331.2 BCF at an annual growth rate of 7%. From 2000 to 2004, gas consumption grew 
at an annual rate of 8%. The country’s total present gas demand is about 1,350 million cubic 
feet per day (MMCFD). Government estimates show that this will increase to 2,420 MMCFD in 
2015 and 3,785 MMCFD in 2025. On a cumulative basis, this is equivalent to a 5% annual 
growth rate and is considered conservative. If this trend persists, Bangladesh will require 105 
MMCFD in 2018 and 4.47 TCF of additional gas from new discoveries by 2025 to meet the 
commercial energy demand. Petrobangla has taken steps to increase the additional available 
gas up to 580 MMCFD by 2008, signing agreements to purchase and save gas from fields of 
Sangu and Moularibazar and Bibiyana. All technical and geological exploratory studies indicate 
that new discoveries will be available to meet the growing gas demand. Current discussions 
among governments on subregional cooperation on natural gas exploration, transmission, and 
distribution would be beneficial to Bangladesh. Additional information on gas supply, demand, 
tariff,  institutions,  policies,  and  a  sector  assessment  is  in  Appendix  2  and  Supplementary 
Appendix A. 
 
2.  Institutional Framework 
4.  In Bangladesh, the oil and gas sector is regulated and administered by the Government, 
but there have been many initiatives for private sector participation (PSP) in some gas sector 
entities and activities during the last few years. The Government, through the Energy and 
Mineral Resources Division (EMRD) of the Ministry of Power, Energy, and Mineral Resources 
(MPEMR), has the authority for policy formulation, investment decision, and regulation. In 1972, 
the Bangladesh Oil, Gas and Minerals Corporation (Petrobangla) was created as a state agency 
for oil and gas exploration, production, transmission, and distribution. Over time, an unbundling 
process was completed by establishing separate companies for production, transmission, and

5.  In the mid-1970s, the Government signed six PSCs with IOCs under the supervision of 
Petrobangla. Since 1994 when the second round of PSCs were entered into with the IOCs 
responsible  for  drilling,  Petrobangla  has  served  as  supervisor  and  sole  purchaser  of  IOC 
outputs.  Due  to  IOC  involvement  in  production,  gas  supply  has  increased.  However,  the 
increased supply is believed to have resulted in less pressure on authorities to continue with the 
needed reforms in SGCs. Meanwhile, deficiencies in the gas supply in relation to demand as 
experienced  in  recent  years  have  once  again  underscored  the  need  for  augmenting  gas 
exploration and production. A recent trend is creating an enabling environment for mobilizing 
private sector resources to finance required investments in these areas. A problem tree analysis 
is given in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 
6.  Private sector involvement in marketing and distribution of liquefied petroleum gas and 
compressed natural gas (CNG) has been initiated and is gathering momentum. Proposals for 
restructuring  two  SGCs  (the  Bakhrabad  Gas  Systems  Limited  [BGSL]  and  Titas  Gas 
Transmission and Distribution Company Limited [TGTDCL]), and offloading shares of the Gas 
Transmission Company Limited (GTCL) are under consideration. The Government is aware that 
future sector governance strategies should emphasize mobilizing the private sector to support 
the demand side of gas development, and increase production and supply. It is also aware of 
the  importance  of  streamlining  the  Government’s  role  in  ensuring  efficient  regulation  and 
responsiveness to various stakeholder interests, expectations, and inputs.  
 
7.  The legal framework for establishing the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC)3 was 
enacted on 13 March 2003. ERC became effective on 27 April 2004 with the appointment of two 
members, one of them acting as chairman. A recent amendment to the Act is designed to 
streamline the selection process. ERC has neither an approved organizational structure nor 
staff to undertake expected tasks. Thus far, ERC has not achieved expected results. In this 
regard,  the  Government  has  agreed  to  appoint  the  two  remaining  members  of  ERC,  and 
thereafter it must be able to function fully. The long-term funding of ERC should be settled 
quickly in a manner that will make it become, and remain, effective. ERC will take over the 
responsibility of tariff setting and other regulating activities.

  1.  System Loss 
 
9.  Under the TNGDP that closed on 23 Oct 2003, the Government agreed that BGSL and 
the  Jalalabad  Gas  Transmission  and  Distribution  Systems  Ltd  (JGTDSL)  maintain  system 
losses in their respective franchise areas at 2% or less for the duration of the Project. BGSL 
maintained system losses less than 2% up to 1999. The losses went up to 4.08% in 2001/02 but 
have come down to about 1% in the past 2 years. JGTDSL maintained system losses less than 
2% throughout the project life except in 1994. In recent years the losses came down to less than 
1%. The Government also agreed that TGTDCL, with advice from consultants appointed under 
the safety and efficiency technical assistance (TA),6 would maintain the level of system losses in 
its franchise area to 2% or less by 30 June 1995 and beyond. However, TGTDCL could not 
maintain system loss to the stipulated level. Its system losses ranged from 6 to 9%. 
 
10.  A 2% transmission and distribution loss is an acceptable norm in the gas industry. The 
cost of gas system loss is substantial, estimated at about Tk2.4 billion. In addition, the cost of 
collection inefficiency is also sizable. Assuming a norm of 98% collection-billing ratio, the cost of 
collection shortfall is estimated at Tk1.8 billion. The TA made several recommendations and 
developed a plan for reducing system loss that includes installation of meters, and privatization 
of meter reading and billing. The plan developed under the TA has been revised and was 
recently adopted by TGTDCL under the supervision of Petrobangla. It is a comprehensive 
efficiency improvement and system loss reduction plan valid for the entire gas sector (Appendix 
3). The plan will be implemented during 2005–2010 in conjunction with the Project, to contain 
system losses at 2% or lower by 2010. (Further details on the system loss reduction plan are in 
Supplementary Appendix D.) Moreover, the Government intends to restructure TGTDCL in a bid 
to improve its management efficiencies.

5.  Policy Dialogue 
a.  Gas Sector Reform and Governance 
 
16.  According to the PRSP, the Government’s sectoral development goals are to (i) provide 
energy for sustainable economic growth and for maintaining energy security in the country; (ii) 
provide energy to all socioeconomic groups in the country, especially to the less developed 
areas; (iii) diversify the use of indigenous energy; and (iv) contribute to the protection of the 
environment.  The  Government’s  gas  sector  policy  also  provides  that  new  exploration  and 
production of oil and gas will predominantly be by the private sector through PSCs. While GTCL 
will be responsible for gas transmission, PSP will be encouraged by allowing construction of 
pipelines through build-own-operate-transfer contracts, with operations managed by GTCL. In 
September 2004, the Government announced the private sector infrastructure guidelines that 
provide for PSP in exploration, production, transmission, and distribution of oil and gas. Such 
projects could be undertaken under build-own-operate (BOO) and build-operate-transfer (BOT). 
In addition, the private sector’s minority equity participation in GTCL will be encouraged. Gas 
marketing and distribution will be commercialized and gradually privatized. The Government’s 
gas sector reform road map (GSRR) is in Appendix 4. The GSRR, to be implemented over 5 
years, covers a wide range of important policy activities including revisions to the energy policy, 
draft Gas Act, gas tariff setting, and sector regulatory mechanism. ADB has worked with the 
Government extensively on developing the GSRR.  
 
17.  The Project addresses governance issues at two levels: first, at the sector level and 
second, at the enterprise level. Sector-level governance issues focus on sector reforms, tariff 
determination, setting up a regulator and defining its functions, and sustainability of energy 
sector operations. These are addressed by streamlining the approval process and implementing

b.  Private Sector Participation 
18.  The Government recognizes that the natural gas sector, with its large potential for 
contributing  to  the  development  of  the  economy,  will  have  to  be  effectively  managed  to

reforms have been implemented in an ad hoc manner, making it difficult for development 
partners and private investors to boost their contribution to the sector’s substantial investment 
needs. Efforts to expand energy coverage for the population will be accelerated to improve the 
poor’s access to natural gas. The exploration and utilization of oil, gas, coal, and mineral 
resources will be expedited; foreign and private investment in these sectors will be encouraged; 
and capabilities of the relevant agencies will be built to achieve the goals.  
 
19.  Public sector resources are limited to provide adequate support to meet the gas sector’s 
essential investments such as increasing gas exploration, further expanding gas transmission

incentives  are  made  available  to  investors  such  as  an  adequate  business  environment.

promoting  PSP  and  assuring  sustainable  development  in  the  gas  sector.11  A  detailed 
examination of sector structure, unbundling of companies, and investment planning will be 
undertaken to meet the reform objectives and to facilitate greater PSP in the gas sector.  
 
c.  Lessons Learned

sector as a whole, have been incorporated in designing the Project. More details on the lessons 
learned and external assistance are in Appendix 5.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
23.  The low utilization of natural gas in Bangladesh has constrained commercial, industrial, 
and rural development. To improve the situation, several major initiatives are being taken in the 
gas sector. Petrobangla’s investment plan for oil, gas, and mineral resources for 2002–2020 is 
one initiative. Another is the implementation of the GSRR. The GSRR covers (i) institutional and 
financial restructuring of gas sector companies to ensure long-term financial sustainability, (ii) 
restructuring of gas sector entities, (iii) strengthening of public–private participation aimed at 
creating an environment for private sector-led growth, (iv) diversification of the ownership of gas 
sector  companies,  (v)  market-oriented  energy  pricing,  and  (vii)  promotion  of  sectoral  e-
governance. The GSRR will be implemented in conjunction with the Project. 
 
24.  The Government’s poverty reduction strategy emphasizes implementation of policies 
directed toward expanding the natural gas grid to cover less developed areas, particularly in the 
western region of the country. The strategy will also accelerate balanced regional development 
that would help reduce widespread poverty. The Project aims to further develop the main 
indigenous  energy  resource  in  Bangladesh  to  meet  the  increasing  demand  for  primary 
commercial  energy.  It  will  increase  the  pace  of  economic  development  in  less  developed 
regions of the country by expanding the sustainable supply and use of natural gas to replace 
polluting fossil and biomass fuels. Use of natural gas will also improve indoor and outdoor air 
quality and reduce respiratory diseases. 
 
B.  Outputs 
25.  The project output is improved and expanded natural gas infrastructure and delivery 
system through an improved and expanded transmission and distribution network and field 
appraisal  support  for  gas  sector  companies.  The  Project  will  also  enhance  financial 
performance,  governance,  and  efficiency  indicators  of  gas  sector  entities  through  capacity

8 
building and implementation of the GSRR. The Project will increase the pace of economic 
development in less developed regions of the country by expanding sustainable gas supply. 
Wider use of natural gas resources to replace fossil and polluting biofuels will improve ambient 
air quality in urban centers as well as indoor air quality in many households. The Project and the 
affiliated GSRR will enhance the role of the private sector in natural gas-related activities, 
including (i) gas exploration and development; (ii) transmission and distribution; and (iii) gas 
metering, audit, and operation and maintenance (O&M) activities. The private sector will also 
have  an  enhanced  role  in  gas-based  or  related  industries,  power  generation,  and  other 
manufacturing and processing activities.

C.  Special Features 
27.  Geographical  Focus.  The  project  scope  was  determined  on  the  basis  of  a 
comprehensive  demand-supply  assessment,  including  regional  demand  analysis,  and 
technically full-fledged network analysis. The gas transmission component of the Project has 
two distinct parts: (i) the north-south system expansion (NSSE), designed to remove the supply 
bottlenecks  in  the  entire  network  including  the  existing  eastern  network;  and  (ii)  the  four 
extension pipelines, which will meet the projected demand in the less developed western region 
of the country. The western region has a weak industrial base, poor infrastructure, lower social 
indicators despite a rich agricultural base. The Project provides the opportunity for the first time 
in western part of Bangladesh to receive natural gas on a large scale to boost its economic 
development and alleviate regional disparities in the long run.  
 
28.  Technology Transfer. Network analysis demonstrates the constraints in the existing 
gas supply system. Facilities that would help overcome these constraints include installation of 
compressors at selected transmission points, and looping, depending on the growth in demand. 
The existing network will not be able to meet the demand beyond 2007, when demand would 
peak  at  1,796  MMCFD.  To  address  this  constraint,  the  NSSE  involves  installation  of 
compression facilities at Muchai and Ashuganj south, together with the recently commissioned 
Rashidpur-Habiganj  loop,  to  augment  the  throughput  from  650  MMCFD  in  2004  to  1,564 
MMCFD in 2009. The Project supports the use of compressors in the gas sector for the first time 
in  the  country  and  promotes  state-of-the  art  technology  transfer.    The  newly  introduced 
innovative  technology  will  continue  to  help  the  gas  sector  of  the  country.  An  additional 
compressor  facility  at  Ashuganj  west  will  be installed  to  maintain  the  supply  to  the  major 
consumption centers in the eastern regions. An additional loop line and compressor at Elenga 
will be installed to ensure an adequate supply to the western region, with or without the three 
extensions to Bheramara, Rajshahi, and Khulna.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Technical Aspects 
43.  The total present gas demand in the country is about 1,350 MMCFD. Government 
estimates show that this will increase to 2,420 MMCFD in 2015 and 3,785 MMCFD in 2025. If 
this trend persists, Bangladesh will require 105 MMCFD in 2018 and 4.47 TCF additional gas by 
2025 from new discoveries to meet its commercial energy demand. All technical exploratory 
studies indicate that Bangladesh has adequate gas reserves to meet its requirements.  
 
44.  Network analysis demonstrates the constraints in the existing gas supply system. The 
least-cost  analysis  shows  that  overcoming  those  constraints  will  involve  installation  of 
compressors at selected transmission points, and looping, depending on the growth in demand. 
The existing network will not be able to meet the demand level beyond 2007, when the peak 
demand would be 1,796 MMCFD. To address these constraints, the NSSE involves installation 
of  compression  facilities  at  Muchai  and  Ashuganj  South.  These  together  with  the  recently 
commissioned Rashidpur-Habiganj loop will augment the throughput of 1,564 MMCFD in 2009. 
Additional compressor facility at Ashuganj west will have to be installed to maintain the supply to 
the major consumption centers in the eastern regions. An additional loop line and compressor at 
Elenga will be installed to allow an adequate supply to the western region, with or without 
extensions to Bheramara, Rajshahi, and Khulna. Such improvements will enable the present 
project design to serve for the natural gas system for the next 25 years or more.

B.  Financial Viability 
45.  Financial evaluation of the Project was carried out in accordance with the Guidelines for 
the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian 
Development Bank. The analysis and computation of the financial internal rate of return (FIRR), 
including sensitivity analysis, were carried out for the (i) pipeline extensions, (ii) existing system 
reinforcement,  and  (iii)  overall  system  including  expansions  and  extensions.  For  the  field 
appraisal component, no FIRR was calculated since there is no revenue stream associated with 
this component and the investment provides a clearer delineation and an increase in reserves 
that have future economic benefit. Financial analysis was undertaken in real terms using 2005 
prices. The without-project and with-project scenarios were compared.  Without the project, the 
ongoing gas shortages in Bangladesh, with frequent power brownouts, would continue. With the 
project, the available gas supply northeast of Bangladesh from newly discovered fields that are 
being developed would be available to meet shortages in the existing gas supply area and also 
to supply the new market areas on the west side of the Jamuna bridge. A summary of the past 
and projected financial performance of the EAs is attached as Appendix 10. More details on 
financial management are given in Supplementary Appendix G. 
 
46.  The overall pipeline and compressor option combined with the extension projects has a 
FIRR of 12.0% computed on an after-tax basis. This FIRR compares favorably with the WACC 
of 3.79%, also computed after tax. Sensitivity analysis was run for increases (+10%) in capital 
and operating and maintenance costs, and a reduction in project benefits (-10%). A combination 
of the increases in costs and decreases in benefits was also tested, together with project delays 
accompanied by increases in project costs. In addition a number of specific sensitivities were 
also analyzed: (i) reduction in wheeling charges to Tk 0.36/thousand cubic feet (MCF) by 15%, 
implying only half real increases prior to July 2008; (ii) increase in compressor fuel consumption 
from 1.5% to 2.5% of gas volumes; (iii) increase in compressor fuel costs from current average 
costs of $0.55/MCF to $1.32/MCF; (iv) reduction in salvage value of pipelines by 50%, reflecting 
a 25-year rather than 40-year life; and (v) a 2-year delay in construction and a 20% increase in 
overall  project  costs. Sensitivity  and  risk  analysis  suggests  that  the  FIRR  is  robust  under 
adverse conditions. Therefore, the Project is considered financially viable. A summary of the 
Project’s financial evaluations is given in Appendix 11 and a more detailed analysis is in the 
Supplementary Appendix H.  
 
C.  Economic Analysis 
47.  Demand Analysis. Future gas demand was analyzed for the area covered by the 
existing pipeline system and for three possible west zone pipeline expansion projects. The 
forecast gas sales level for the existing network area was the basis for estimating increased 
volumes and benefits from network expansion. The analysis assumed that the present network 
system would not meet demand above the 2007 level, and that increased gas sales above at 
level would be due entirely to investment in the network. The capital and operating costs of the 
main transmission system project investments were allocated among the subprojects on the 
basis of future gas sales over the evaluation period, with sales held constant from 2017 to 2027. 
Most of the existing system and extensions were expected to be at capacity by 2017. The 
expected increase in gas consumption over the next 22 years (with consumption constant from 
2017) would be 8.5 million MMCF. Of this, 80% is related to growth within the existing network 
and 20% from the proposed extensions (Appendix 12). 
 
48.  Least-Cost Analysis. The network analysis has been validated for the entire system, 
and changing any one element may affect the entire system. However, between any two points,

16 
compressors or looping alternatives can be compared. The planned investment program is 
based on numerous simulation runs to identify the locations where bottlenecks develop as 
throughput increases and to remove those bottlenecks with compressors or looping. For all 
compressor locations identified as bottlenecks, costs of the pipeline looping alternative were 
estimated. Capital costs differenced by about $189 million between the two proposals in favor of 
compressors. The operating and maintenance (O&M) costs per year for pipe and compressors 
are typically about 1% and 2.5% of the installed costs, respectively. The various pipeline size 
options for the extensions on the west side of the Jamuna Bridge, based on demand forecasts 
were also evaluated. The length of the extensions and pressure regime on the main line and 
economies  of  scale  on  compressor  utilization  resulted  in  the  least-cost  solution  for  the 
extensions at $169.2 million compared with the option ($253.7 million) originally proposed by 
GTCL. Details are given in Supplementary Appendix I. 
 
49.   Economic Rate of Return. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated 
for the Project to assess its economic viability. The costs considered were capital costs, and 
O&M costs. Appropriate conversion factors were used to convert financial values into economic 
values. Values are expressed in 2005 prices. The main economic benefit of the Project is the 
value of future imported petroleum fuels and indigenous energy sources that gas would displace 
with the extension of the transmission pipeline into the less developed areas of the country, and 
growth in demand from new and existing customers in the existing gas supply area. The EIRR 
was computed at 28.1% for the Project (Appendix 12). Sensitivity and risk analyses simulating 
adverse  scenarios  showed  the  project  EIRR  to  be  stable  and  robust.  More  details  are  in 
Supplementary Appendix J.

are  expected  to  be  multidimensional.  Poverty  analysis  was  carried  out  during  the  project

restructuring measures. Continued policy dialogue with the Government on the agreed-upon 
time frame to implement the GSRR would alleviate this risk. Another concern is the availability 
of the required gas supply during the Project’s economic life. Bangladesh’s exploration-to-
discovery ratio is significantly high. With adequate investments, such a risk can be mitigated. 
Furthermore, the Government has agreed to encourage and accelerate exploration activities in 
both public and private sectors to ensure timely reserve replacement and gas availability. This is 
a loan assurance in implementing the GSRR.

GAS SECTOR ASSESSMENT 
 
1.  Total proven and probable recoverable gas reserves from 22 fields in Bangladesh are 
estimated at 20.4 trillion cubic feet (TCF), of which 5.09 TCF has so far been consumed. The 
current net recoverable reserves stand at 15.3 TCF. Of the 22 gas fields, 20 have so far been 
brought under production. Fourteen of them are currently under production, and six are not 
producing at this time. A recent study conducted by the Hydrocarbon Unit in cooperation with 
the  Norwegian  Petroleum  Directorate  has  estimated  Bangladesh’s  remaining  recoverable 
proven and probable gas reserves at just over 16 TCF. 15 The study concludes that, taking the 
discovered and undiscovered reserves together, there is a 90% probability that Bangladesh’s 
gas resource will exceed 30 TCF. Some estimates indicate an undiscovered potential of up to 
88 TCF,16 about 5.5 times the reserves of 15.9 TCF proven and probable recoverable gas 
discovered to date that has been in production. 
2.  A study17 in 2001 presents a base case with a growth rate of 4.7% between 2004 and 
2020, a high growth rate case of 6.5% and a low growth rate case of 3.4%. The forecast 
demand for 2020 corresponding to these assumed growth rates has a plus 38% minus 33% 
range around the base case. The difference between the high and low cases represents the 
demand of 1,692 million cubic feet per day (MMCFD), which is greater than the total present 
demand of 1,240 MMCFD. Gas consumption in Bangladesh in the last decade rose from 172.7 
billion cubic feet (BCF) to 331.2 BCF at an annual growth rate of 7%. However, in 2000–2004, 
gas consumption increased at an annual growth of 8%. Average consumption in the different 
sectors was 8% for power (from 399 MMCFD to 544.4 MMCFD), 2% for fertilizer (from 232.6 
MMCFD to 254.3 MMCFD), and 13% for all the nonbulk sectors (from 278.2 MMCFD to 448.4 
MMCFD). In the nonbulk sectors, captive power has marked the highest growth of 33% (27.3 
MMCFD to 84.5MMCFD) followed by domestic use of 13% (81.3 MMCFD to 134.9 MMCFD), 
industry 10% (98.3 to 141.3MMCFD), and commercial use 6% etc. 
 
3.  The forecast balance between peak gas demand and peak gas supply indicates that the 
current deficit of 103–200 MMCFD will change to a surplus of about 200 MMCFD during 2007–
2010. This will, however, change to a deficit of increasing size after 2013. If no new reserves 
are added to the existing ones, the country will encounter a net deficit of about 249 MMCFD in 
2016, which will rise sharply to 4,421 MMCFD by 2025. About 23.225 TCF gas would be 
required to meet the gas demand (high case scenario) over the projection period, of which 
14.871 TCF would be met from the existing reserve and 8.354 TCF would be required to be 
replenished through new discoveries or from alternative sources. All technical assessments 
indicate that new reserves could be discovered with adequate investments. 
 
4.  The  scale  of  the  required  investments  implies  that  the  private  sector  can  have  a 
significant  role  in  the  gas  sector  provided  that  the  right  incentives  are  made  available  to 
investors. After discussions with the Government, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved 
technical assistance (TA)18 to assist the Government in promoting private sector participation 
and assuring sustainable development in the gas sector. A detailed examination of sectoral 
structure, unbundling of transmission and distribution companies, and investment planning will 
be undertaken to meet the reform objectives and to facilitate greater private sector participation 
in the gas sector. TA implementation will start soon.

A.  External Assistance 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been involved in the gas sector intermittently 
over the last 30 years and provided eight loans totaling $446 million. The role of ADB has 
evolved from provider of funds for individual products to a more proactive one that is more 
comprehensive, involving technical advice for project preparation (since the 1980s) and policy 
advice in implementing sector reforms (since the 1990s). ADB has also given 16 technical 
assistance (TA) grants worth $4.9 million for improving operational efficiencies, preparing a gas 
master plan, drafting a gas law, developing a policy on private sector participation (PSP) in gas 
pipeline construction evaluating options for PSP in the Rashidpur-Ashuganj gas pipeline, and 
examination of personnel-related issues in the sector. Development of the downstream market 
in promoting the use of natural gas for the transport sector has also been supported through the 
Dhaka Clean Fuel Project.20  
 
2.  The World Bank entered the sector in 1980, and during 1980–1995, provided four loans 
totaling $344 million. World Bank support was extended for developing transmission systems, 
developing gas fields, and preparing a package for attracting PSP in oil and gas exploration. 
World  Bank  also  supported  Petrobangla  and  gas  sector  entities  in  developing  financial 
management and a management information system. It is currently supporting Petrobangla in 
preparing a gas sector master plan. Belgium, Canada, France, Japan, Netherlands, and United 
Kingdom also supported the sector intermittently in exploration, production, transmission, and 
distribution. In addition to ADB, the Japan International Cooperation Authority (JICA) and US 
Trade Development Agency (USTDA) have supported studies on optimization of gas use; the 
Norwegian Agency for Development is assisting in establishing and supporting the hydrocarbon 
unit (HCU), a think tank for policy advice within the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources 
(MEMR);  and  the  Canadian  International  Development  Agency  (CIDA)  has  supported  the 
introduction of vehicles fueled by compressed natural gas (CNG). External assistance to the gas 
sector from ADB and other sources such as the World Bank, Japan, and the United Kingdom 
from 1993 to 2002 are in Table A5.

loans and one private sector investment totaling about $1.4 billion, and 20 TA grants totaling 
about  $9.6  million  from  ADB.  ADB  recently  evaluated  its  power  assistance  program21  in

ownership of TAs; and (iv) improve financial management capacities.

projects and newly created entities, the approach clearly demonstrates the direction that future

6.  ADB’s Country Assistance Program Evaluation22 notes that, as the lead funding agency

processing and administration of contracts and the timely availability of Government funding;

FINANCIAL EVALUATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The financial analysis (FA) of the Project has been carried out in accordance with the 
Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by 
the Asian Development Bank. The FA was conducted for only the gas transmission component 
of the Project. The evaluation and computation of the financial internal rate of return (FIRR), 
including sensitivity evaluation, were carried out for the (i) pipeline extensions, (ii) existing 
system reinforcement, and (iii) overall system including expansions and extensions. The FA is 
carried out in a manner consistent with the assumptions in the economic analysis. FA for each 
subproject compared the FIRR with the weighted average cost of capital (WACC). Sensitivity 
tests were undertaken to assess the impact on the FIRR of project risks as reflected in cost 
increases,  revenue  decreases,  and  construction  delays.  Without-project  and  with-project 
scenarios were compared. Without the Project, the ongoing gas shortages in Bangladesh with 
frequent power brownouts would continue. With the Project, the available gas supply in the 
northeast of Bangladesh from newly discovered fields, which are being developed, would be 
available to meet gas shortages in the existing gas supply area and also serve the new market 
areas on the west side of the Jamuna bridge.  
 
B.  Assumptions 
2.  The Project was evaluated over a 20-year period based on a 15-year design horizon to 
2017. Project benefit and cost streams were held constant from 2017 to 2027. The financial 
evaluation considered only the incremental revenues and costs directly associated with the 
Project. All costs and revenues are expressed in 2005 prices. Capital costs included physical 
contingencies, but exclude price contingencies and interest during construction for the period 
2005–2009.  An  average  exchange  rate  of  Tk60.0  per  $1.00  was  used  to  convert  foreign 
exchange costs to local currency equivalent in January 2005. Repair and maintenance costs of 
project assets were based on estimates adopted in the economic evaluation. The allowance of 
2.5% of capital costs for compressor maintenance other than fuel included annual overhauls 
and any major overhauls that would maintain the life of the asset for 20 years. Proper routine 
maintenance was assumed.  
 
C.  Weighted Average Cost of Capital  and Financial Internal Rate of Return 
 
3.  The risk-free interest rate for Bangladesh is a government-guaranteed 10-year bonds 
and they have an interest rate of 10%. For shorter terms, interest rates are up to 13%.  A 5% 
spread for sector and company risk was assumed for the indicative borrowing rate of 15% for 
long-term  borrowings.  Given  the  relatively  stable  cash  flows  that  can  be  expected  from 
transmission operations, a return to equity of 2% over corporate borrowing rates was assumed. 
Rather than apply a beta factor, a further interest rate spread of 1% was assigned. When 
combined with the risk-free interest rate, the cost of equity was 18%. The Government-set

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Estimation of Costs 
 
1.  Economic costs are in 2005 prices. Tradable commodities were valued at border prices 
at the prevailing exchange rate. Nontradable commodities were valued through shadow prices 
using a standard conversion factor. The capital costs, based on least-cost analysis, were also 
adjusted to eliminate inflation, interest during construction, and taxes. Capital costs include 
investments required in facilities to provide incremental gas sales and maintenance of the 
existing gas system, and in gas distribution networks to support nonbulk customer sales of gas. 
The estimation of costs also includes the calculation of a depletion premium. 
 
B.  Estimation of Benefits 
2.  The main economic benefit of the Project is the value of future imported petroleum fuels 
and indigenous energy sources that gas would displace with the extensions of the transmission 
pipeline into the less developed areas, and growth in demand from new and existing customers 
in the existing gas supply area. The demand for gas was projected by taking into account all 
new end users, the growth in demand from existing gas consumers, and the substituted gas 
consumption by self-generated power using gas oil and gasoline (because of gas supply and 
transmission  deficiencies).  The  demand  projections  are  based  on  a  conservative  growth 
scenario and include the likely completion of power plants planned on the basis of the power 
sector master plan. More details of the least cost analysis is in Supplementary Appendix I. 
 
3.  The bulk of the additional gas volume consumed as a result of the pipeline will be non-
incremental  sales  to  new  customers.  For  the  expansion  and  reinforcement  of  the  existing 
network,  all  sales  are  also  nonincremental  in  nature.  No  major  incremental  benefits  are 
expected from the Project, with all economic benefits valued as nonincremental sales in terms 
of resource cost savings. Quantifiable benefits in terms of resource cost savings are derived 
from international border prices adjusted for local transport to project locations, and for fuels 
displaced by gas over the forecast period. The quantity of heavy fuel oil (HFO) required for 
power stations in the absence of gas supply is reduced by 50% to reflect the practicality that 
these would not be built if HFO was the only source, or, alternatively, further mine-mouth coal 
fired power stations would be built in preference to importing HFO. 
 
4.  Based  on  the  economic  fuel  costs  assuming  90%  of  the  International  Bank  for 
Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) oil projections, the value of benefits based on the 
economic value of fuels displaced by gas in the main line market growth and three western zone 
expansion  projects  is  estimated  at  $643  million  in  2010  and  $2,220  million  in  2017  (at 
$4.14/thousand cubic feet [MCF] and $4.31/MCF, respectively). Bulk fuel substitution represents 
79% of the economic benefits and nonbulk comprises 21% (predominantly domestic substitution 
of  cooking  fuel  sources)  of  economic  benefits.  In  2017,  the  mainline  expansion  and 
reinforcement projects will provide 85% of the overall economic benefits.  
 
C.  Estimation of Economic Internal Rate of Return 
5.  The basis for project evaluation is a comparison of benefits and costs between the 
project (base) case and the without-project (alternative) case. The project analysis period is 22 
years following expected full operation by 2011. The project construction period is 5 years from 
2005 to 2010. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated at 28.1%, indicating 
that the Project is economically viable (Table A12.1).

F.  Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
7.  Implementation  of  the  RP  will  be  monitored  regularly.  A  computerized  management

project expenses and implementation within limits and schedules. The CMIS will provide household

financial reports. The PMU will establish a quarterly monitoring system involving staff of the IAs and 
implementing NGO staff. The PMU will prepare quarterly progress reports on all aspects of land 
acquisition and resettlement activities. The report will contain progress made in RP implementation 
with particular attention to compliance with the principles and matrix set out in the RP. With ADB 
concurrence, the EA will engage in an independent monitoring agency to carry out annual external 
monitoring of the resettlement operations. The external monitor will be selected within 3 months of 
loan approval.

C.  Disclosure, Consultation and Grievances 
 
6.  Government  authorities,  local  community  groups,  and  members  of  the  public  were 
consulted during preparation of the IEEs. The ADB team also visited project sites and held 
consultations with local communities whose land will be affected during construction and with 
local business leaders. Further structured consultations will continue, and the EMP will be 
improved accordingly. For the resettlement work, a Grievance Redress Committee (GRC) has 
been set up to address all concerns and grievances.  
 
D.  Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
7.  The  EMP  will  include  both  internal  and  external  monitoring.  The  environmental 
specialists in the project management units (PMUs) will be responsible for internal monitoring of 
EMP implementation, and will forward quarterly progress reports to the EA. The reports will 
contain progress made in EMP implementation, with particular attention to compliance with the 
principles and matrix set out in the EMP. The Gas Transmission Company Limited (GTCL) and 
Pashchimanchal Gas Company Limited (PGCL) will submit semiannual monitoring reports to 
ADB. With ADB concurrence, GTCL and PGCL will hire an independent individual expert to 
undertake  external  monitoring  of  the  entire  Project.  The  independent  monitor  who  will  be 
selected within 3 months of loan approval, will report on a semiannual basis directly to ADB, 
determine  whether  sound  environmental  management  practices  have  been  achieved,  and 
suggest  suitable  recommendations  of  remedial  measures  for  midterm  correction  and 
improvement. The summary environmental monitoring plan is in Table A15.3 and the cost

successfully mitigated by implementing the component-specific EMPs. On the basis of the IEEs, 
there is no need for a full environmental impact assessment. However, the EAs will need to 
strengthen their capabilities to implement and monitor the EMPs. This need has been designed 
into  the  project  by  requiring  environmental  specialists  in  the  PMUs  and  the  hiring  of  an
